awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Supporting and Learning From Principal Investigators “Making the Leap to Large”
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is to document the views of a unique set of researches all of whom aspire to lead large-scale science and engineering research projects through stakeholder mapping survey methods. It will also develop exploratory methodology to deliver serial virtual workshop sessions at scale that prepare researchers to conceptualize, plan, and execute high impact large projects. To accommodate the virtual format, the project serialized delivery over 7 weeks and revised the pedagogy so that each session could be an integrated package of pre-recorded video, live keynote speakers, formal presentation, short exercises completed in small break-out groups, and interactive surveys for participant feedback. This proposal will allow for engaging professionals who can seamlessly deliver these materials in real time to over 1,000 simultaneous participants and identify which elements are most effective. Stakeholder mapping surveys will be used both to provide reflective input to the participants and to advance the science of science and engineering and better understand the interests and capabilities of researchers who aspire to lead large-scale science and engineering projects.

This proposal will improve investigator understanding and capability for advancing the scientific, economic, workforce, and innovation impacts of their research. It will expand national capacity to lead large-scale science and engineering research projects.  It will also support long-term hosting of the workshop series for on-going community reuse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Large-scale science and engineering research projects have transformative potential in society. Success in these large research projects depends not just on scientific merit, but also on organizational and institutional factors: stakeholder alignment, performance measurement, project leadership, data management, people development, and bridging across fields and disciplines. The “Leap to Large” seminar series on these topics drew over 1,400 pre-registrants, which led to this grant to support a digital infrastructure, explainer videos, and stakeholder alignment surveys. While a fall-off was anticipated, an infrastructure that could support hundreds of participants was needed.

Attendance at the sessions ranged from approximately 250 to 700. A core group of 250-350 attended most sessions, and represent a national resource of scholars building capability for large-scale science and engineering research projects. 

During the workshop, a LinkedIn Group was formed (https://www.linkedin.com/groups/12529600/) that now has nearly 200 members, though additional curation and leadership of this community is needed. 

The Stakeholder Bargaining Game Exercise was developed under this grant and is available on request from Joel Cutcher-Gershenfeld (joelcg@brandeis.edu). We are exploring ways to make it open-access (right now set up by an administrator is needed).

Session 1: Foundations for large-scale success and impact - April 6, 2021

· Welcome: Margaret Martonosi, NSF

· Keynote: Stefan Savage, University of California, San Diego

· Animation: https://youtu.be/GZ5wD2zl6eo 

· Recording: Intro – Science Impact: https://youtu.be/f8kcGuCZJ_A 

Session 2: Stakeholder alignment - April 13, 2021

· Keynote: Kate Keahey, Argonne National Laboratory

· Animation: Stakeholders: https://youtu.be/MhVF-UVQ_fk 

· Recording: Stakeholder Alignment: https://youtu.be/7R0MImbx6vQ

Session 3: Performance measurement and feedback - April 20, 2021

· Keynote: John Towns, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign

· Animation: Measurement: https://youtu.be/PS2eSIiuQ_E 

· Recording: Performance Measurement: https://youtu.be/QsBvt2rVaZQ 

Session 4: Project leadership - April 27, 2021

· Keynotes: Muffet McGraw, University of Notre Dame; Neil Gershenfeld and Sherry Lassiter, MIT Center for Bits and Atoms and Fab Foundation

· Animation: Leadership: https://youtu.be/mV5mRecqmws 

· Recording: Project Leadership: https://youtu.be/Ty0wCsG1dVI 

Session 5: Data management - May 4, 2021

· Panel: Christine Kirkparick, University of California, San Diego; Steve Diggs, Scripps Institution of Oceanography; and Kerstin Lehnert, Columbia University

· Keynote: Kimberly Claffy, University of California, San Diego

· Animation: Data Management: https://youtu.be/7MWPXESJivg 

· Recording: Data Management: https://youtu.be/wODhlN1bl58 

Session 6: People development - May 11, 2021

· Keynote: Julia Lane, New York University

· Animation: Workforce: https://youtu.be/6jYyBKsxPTk 

· Recording: Workforce: https://youtu.be/38LQRaiUbm4 

Session 7: Collaboration across fields and disciplines - May 18, 2021

· Keynote: Nadya Bliss, Arizona State University

· Animation: Collaboration: https://youtu.be/BiEiE7IVUNc 

· Recording: Collaboration: https://youtu.be/YCswgDqmR3g 

· Concluding Comments: Gurdip Singh, NSF


Last Modified: 06/08/2022
Modified by: Joel E Cutcher-Gershenfeld
